revision.text: {| class=wikitable style="float: right; margin:5px;" |-align="center" |'''Legend''' |-bgcolor=#CCCCCC |'''[[Space observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#0000A0 |'''[[Gravitational Observatory|Gravitational Observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#0000FF |'''[[Antimatter observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#00FFFF |'''[[Airborne observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#99CC99 |'''[[Radio telescope|Radio observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#00FF00 |'''[[Submillimetre astronomy|Microwave observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#FFFFFF |'''[[Observatory#Ground-based_observatories|Ground based observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#FFFF99 |'''[[Solar telescope|Solar observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#FFCC66 |'''[[Neutrino observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#FFCC00 |'''[[Cosmic-ray observatory]]''' |} This is a '''list of astronomical observatories''' ordered by name, along with initial dates of operation (where an accurate date is available) and location. The list also includes a final year of operation for many observatories that are no longer in operation. While other sciences, such as [[volcanology]] and [[meteorology]], also use facilities called observatories for research and observations, this list is limited to observatories that are used to observe celestial objects. [[Observatory#Astronomical observatories|Astronomical observatories]] are mainly divided into four categories: space based, airborne, ground based and underground based. Many modern telescopes and observatories are located in space to observe astronomical objects in [[wavelength]]s of the [[electromagnetic spectrum]] that cannot penetrate the Earth's atmosphere (such as [[ultraviolet]] radiation, [[X-rays]], and [[gamma rays]]) and are thus impossible to observe using ground-based telescopes.{{cite book | last = Chaisson| first = Eric| coauthors = McMillan, Steve| title = Astronomy Today, Fourth Edition| publisher = [[Prentice Hall]]| date = 2002}} Being above the atmosphere, these [[Space observatory|space observatories]] can also avoid the effects of [[atmospheric turbulence]] that plague ground based telescopes, although new generations of [[adaptive optic]]s telescopes have since then dramatically improve the situation on the ground. The space high vacuum environment also allow to free the detectors from the ancestral [[Diurnal motion|diurnal cycle]] due to the atmospheric blue light background of the sky, therefore increasing significantly the observation time. An intermediate variant is the [[airborne observatory]], specialised in the [[infrared]] wavelengths of the EM spectrum, that conduct observations above the part of the atmosphere containing [[water vapor]] that absorbs them, in the [[stratosphere]]. Historically, [[Observatory#Astronomical observatories|astronomical observatories]] consisted generally in a building or group of buildings where observations of [[astronomy|astronomical]] objects such as [[sunspot]]s, [[planets]], [[asteroids]], [[comet]]s, [[star]]s, [[nebula]]e, and [[galaxy|galaxies]] in the [[Visible spectrum|visible]] wavelengths of the electromagnetic spectrum were conducted. At first, for millennia, astronomical observations have been made with naked eyes. Then with the discovery of [[optics]], with the help of different types of [[refractor telescope]]s and later with [[reflector telescope]]s. Their use allowed to dramatically increase both the [[Optical_telescope#Light-gathering power|collecting power]] and [[Angular resolution|limit of resolution]], thus the [[brightness]], level of detail and apparent [[angular size]] of distant celestial objects allowing them to be better studied and understood. Following the development of modern [[physics]], new ground based facilities have been constructed to conduct research in the radio and [[microwave]] wavelengths of the electromagnetic spectrum, with [[radio telescope]]s and dedicated [[Submillimetre astronomy|microwave telescope]]s. Modern [[astrophysics]] has extended the field of study of celestial bodies to non electromagnetic vectors, such as [[neutrino]]s, [[neutron]]s and [[cosmic-ray]]s or [[gravitational wave]]s. Thus new types of observatories have been developed. [[Interferometer]]s are at the core of gravitational wave detectors. In order to limit the natural or artificial [[background noise]], most [[particle detector]] based observatories are build [[Underground_mining_%28hard_rock%29#Development mining vs. production mining|deep underground]]. {{CompactTOC}} == A == [[Image:Arecibo 66.75261W 18.34607N.jpg|thumb|175px|right|Satellite image of [[Arecibo Observatory]]]] {| class="wikitable" "background:light blue; {| class=wikitable style="float: right; margin:5px;" |-align="center" |'''Legend''' |-bgcolor=#CCCCCC |'''[[Space observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#0000A0 |'''[[Gravitational Observatory|Gravitational Observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#0000FF |'''[[Antimatter observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#00FFFF |'''[[Airborne observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#99CC99 |'''[[Radio telescope|Radio observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#00FF00 |'''[[Submillimetre astronomy|Microwave observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#FFFFFF |'''[[Observatory#Ground-based_observatories|Ground based observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#FFFF99 |'''[[Solar telescope|Solar observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#FFCC66 |'''[[Neutrino observatory]]''' |-bgcolor=#FFCC00 |'''[[Cosmic-ray observatory]]''' |} This is a '''list of astronomical observatories''' ordered by name, along with initial dates of operation (where an accurate date is available) and location. The list also includes a final year of operation for many observatories that are no longer in operation. While other sciences, such as [[volcanology]] and [[meteorology]], also use facilities called observatories for research and observations, this list is limited to observatories that are used to observe celestial objects. [[Observatory#Astronomical observatories|Astronomical observatories]] are mainly divided into four categories: space based, airborne, ground based and underground based. Many modern telescopes and observatories are located in space to observe astronomical objects in [[wavelength]]s of the [[electromagnetic spectrum]] that cannot penetrate the Earth's atmosphere (such as [[ultraviolet]] radiation, [[X-rays]], and [[gamma rays]]) and are thus impossible to observe using ground-based telescopes.{{cite book | last = Chaisson| first = Eric| coauthors = McMillan, Steve| title = Astronomy Today, Fourth Edition| publisher = [[Prentice Hall]]| date = 2002}} Being above the atmosphere, these [[Space observatory|space observatories]] can also avoid the effects of [[atmospheric turbulence]] that plague ground based telescopes, although new generations of [[adaptive optic]]s telescopes have since then dramatically improve the situation on the ground. The space high vacuum environment also allow to free the detectors from the ancestral [[Diurnal motion|diurnal cycle]] due to the atmospheric blue light background of the sky, therefore increasing significantly the observation time. An intermediate variant is the [[airborne observatory]], specialised in the [[infrared]] wavelengths of the EM spectrum, that conduct observations above the part of the atmosphere containing [[water vapor]] that absorbs them, in the [[stratosphere]]. Historically, [[Observatory#Astronomical observatories|astronomical observatories]] consisted generally in a building or group of buildings where observations of [[astronomy|astronomical]] objects such as [[sunspot]]s, [[planets]], [[asteroids]], [[comet]]s, [[star]]s, [[nebula]]e, and [[galaxy|galaxies]] in the [[Visible spectrum|visible]] wavelengths of the electromagnetic spectrum were conducted. At first, for millennia, astronomical observations have been made with naked eyes. Then with the discovery of [[optics]], with the help of different types of [[refractor telescope]]s and later with [[reflector telescope]]s. Their use allowed to dramatically increase both the [[Optical_telescope#Light-gathering power|collecting power]] and [[Angular resolution|limit of resolution]], thus the [[brightness]], level of detail and apparent [[angular size]] of distant celestial objects allowing them to be better studied and understood. Following the development of modern [[physics]], new ground based facilities have been constructed to conduct research in the radio and [[microwave]] wavelengths of the electromagnetic spectrum, with [[radio telescope]]s and dedicated [[Submillimetre astronomy|microwave telescope]]s. Modern [[astrophysics]] has extended the field of study of celestial bodies to non electromagnetic vectors, such as [[neutrino]]s, [[neutron]]s and [[cosmic-ray]]s or [[gravitational wave]]s. Thus new types of observatories have been developed. [[Interferometer]]s are at the core of gravitational wave detectors. In order to limit the natural or artificial [[background noise]], most [[particle detector]] based observatories are build [[Underground_mining_%28hard_rock%29#Development mining vs. production mining|deep underground]]. {{CompactTOC}} == A == [[Image:Arecibo 66.75261W 18.34607N.jpg|thumb|175px|right|Satellite image of [[Arecibo Observatory]]]] {| class="wikitable" "background:light blue;
